bestBHT.bht: In this encounter, the religious leaders seek to test Jesus by presenting a woman caught in adultery. Their question about the punishment for adultery aims to trap Him, but Jesus skillfully navigates the situation. While stoning was the specified punishment for a betrothed woman guilty of adultery, their intention was not to uphold the law, but purely to catch Jesus. This situation reveals the true motives of the religious leaders and serves as a foreshadowing of the ultimate defeat they will face for opposing Jesus.

Henry Alford: The very fact of their questioning thus, ‘Moses commanded,... but what sayest Thou?’ belongs to the last days of the Lord’s ministry.
The Rabbis taught that every punishment of death in Scripture put absolutely, without specification, was to be understood as meaning strangulation.
I would rather suppose that from Deut. xxii. 21, 23, 24, an inference was drawn what kind of a death was intended in ver. 22, the crime being regarded as the same.
Albert Barnes: The punishment of adultery commanded by Moses was death.
The Jews had themselves, in the time of Christ, determined that it should be by stoning.
If the adulteress was the daughter of a priest, the punishment was being burned to death.
Philip Schaff: The words ‘concerning her,’ which do not occur in the Authorised Version, but which the best authorities lead us to accept, throw light upon the scene.
It is not a mere abstract contrast between Moses and a new Lawgiver that is before us: it is a special case.
By the way in which Jesus deals with this woman shall the end of His enemies be gained.
Archibald T. Robertson: Stoning was specified for the case of a betrothed woman guilty of adultery...In other cases just death was commanded.
This case may have strictly come within the regulation as a betrothed virgin.
This was the whole point, to catch Jesus, not to punish the woman.
John Gill: Not in Leviticus 20:10; for though according to the law there, an adulteress, one that was a married woman, and so an adulterer, that was a married man, were to be put to death; yet the death was not stoning, but strangling
a daughter of Israel must be stoned, who is betrothed, but not married
if all adulterers were punished with stoning, according to the law, the stones would be consumed; but they would not be consumed
